description: From Middle English verbe, directly from Latin verbum (“word, verb”) and possibly or reinforced by Old French verbe, from Proto-Indo-European *werdʰo-. Doublet of verve and word.

entries.meaning: (grammar) A word that indicates an action, event, or state of being.
examples: The word “speak” is an English verb.

entries.meaning: (figurative) An action as opposed to a trait or thing.
examples: Kindness is a verb, not an adjective. You're only kind if you do kind things.

entries.meaning: (programming) A named command that performs a specific operation on an object.
examples: You can invoke the Properties OLE verb in many ways. The easiest way is to move the mouse over the border of the control until it becomes only a four-way pointer and then right-click.

entries.meaning: (grammar) A word that indicates an action, event, or state of being.
(figurative) An action as opposed to a trait or thing.
(programming) A named command that performs a specific operation on an object.

verbs.description: verb (third-person singular simple present verbs, present participle verbing, simple past and past participle verbed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, nonstandard, colloquial) To use any word that is or was not a verb (especially a noun) as if it were a verb.
examples: Haig, in congressional hearings before his confirmatory, paradoxed his auditioners by abnormalling his responds so that verbs were nouned, nouns verbed and adjectives adverbised. He techniqued a new way to vocabulary his thoughts so as to informationally uncertain anybody listening about what he had actually implicationed... .

entries.meaning: (used as a neutral, unspecific verb, often in linguistics and the social sciences) To perform any action that is normally expressed by a verb.
examples: For example, one-part versions of the proposition "The doctor pursued the lawyer" were "The doctor verbed the object," ...
